Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The initial planning meeting for the next season's adult faith formation series is on the calendar.
Story:
I was just about to log into the planning meeting for the adult faith formation series when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, my old college friend, his name lighting up the screen with a video call request. I hesitated, already feeling the familiar tug-of-war inside me. Mark’s message popped up: “Hey, can you hop on for a sec? These furniture instructions are a nightmare.” I could almost hear the frustration in his voice, and I knew he wouldn’t ask unless he really needed help. As a friend, I wanted to be there for him, especially since he’d just moved and was trying to settle in.

But as a priest, I had a responsibility to the parish. The planning meeting was important—parents and catechists were counting on me to guide the new season, and I’d promised to bring fresh ideas. I could picture the committee waiting, expecting me to lead with focus and care. My heart pounded as I stared at the two screens, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. I wanted to be a good friend, but I also couldn’t let down my community. The minutes ticked by, and I sat frozen, torn between two worlds.
